# Django Best Practices: Custom User Model

### Django ships with a built-in User model for authentication and if you'd like a basic tutorial on how to implement log in, log out, sign up.


## as a general rule, always use a custom user model for all new Django projects.

### AbstractUser vs AbstractBaseUser
####  AbstractUser is a full User model, complete with fields, as an abstract class so that you can inherit from it and add your own profile fields and methods.

![django](https://simpleisbetterthancomplex.com/media/2021/07/custom-user-diagram.png)



#### AbstractBaseUser only contains the authentication functionality, but no actual fields: you have to supply them when you subclass.

![pic](data:image/png;base64,)

#### There are two modern ways to create a custom user model in Django: AbstractUser and AbstractBaseUser. In both cases we can subclass them to extend existing functionality however AbstractBaseUser requires much, much more work. 


### Custom User Model
#### Creating our initial custom user model requires four steps:

- update django_project/settings.py
- create a new CustomUser model
- create new UserCreation and UserChangeForm
- update the admin
